Subdivided flats are evil by late 20th century.  But Hong Kong does not know where to put the people, because they have to be somewhere, have a base.  What could and should be a temporary situation is permanent residence for the unfortunate ones.  An apartment unit can be very small.  But it needs to be long-term functionally effective in providing a pleasant enough living environment that is reasonable to call home.  Subdivision was popular in Hong Kong in the 50's, and was fading out by the late '60's.  This comeback is a great leap backward.

Summary 	â€¢	**ğŸ  Extreme Housing Costs: Hong Kong ranks as the worldâ€™s least affordable housing market, with homes costing nearly 20 times the average annual income. 	â€¢	**ğŸ§â€â™‚ï¸ Tiny Living Spaces: Hundreds of thousands live in â€œcage homesâ€ and subdivided units as small as 75 square feetâ€”smaller than a typical parking space. 	â€¢	**ğŸ˜ï¸ Subdivided Living Strategy: Larger flats are converted into micro-units sharing communal facilities like kitchens and bathrooms to cut costs. 	â€¢	**ğŸŒ³ Land Mismanagement, Not Scarcity: Although 75% of Hong Kongâ€™s land is undeveloped, only 3.7% is zoned for urban housing, highlighting a policy failure rather than a land shortage. 	â€¢	**ğŸ’¼ Governmentâ€™s Role in Real Estate Pricing: The government owns nearly all land and leases it at auction to the highest biddersâ€”often Chinese developersâ€”resulting in skyrocketing prices. 	â€¢	**ğŸ’° Low Taxes, High Land Prices: With minimal tax income, the government relies on land lease revenue, accounting for 30% of public fundingâ€”thus resisting reforms that could lower housing prices. 	â€¢	**âš°ï¸ Coffin Homes & Capsule Innovations: Some live in extremely cramped â€œcoffin homesâ€; others opt for modern capsules by entrepreneurs like Eric Wongâ€”still temporary solutions to a systemic problem. 	â€¢	**âš–ï¸ Need for Zoning Reform: Experts agree that lasting solutions must come from government-led zoning and policy reform, prioritizing people over market profits.  Insights Based on Numbers 	â€¢	20x Annual Income: Illustrates the profound unaffordability. 	â€¢	75-140 sq ft units: Tangible proof of how cramped urban living has become. 	â€¢	3.7% of land zoned for housing: A shockingly low figure in a densely populated city. 	â€¢	30% government revenue from land sales: Reveals why the system persistsâ€”land auctions are a fiscal lifeline.

I lived in a 365 square feet appartement for 8 years inn of the richest cities in the world; Geneva Switzerland. I had to move out of a comfortable appartement because the upstairs neighbors were importantly noisy and I couldn't sleep or have any peace of mind. I thought it was temporary maybe for one year but then it was very hard to find another place and it too not far off ten years. The advantages were almost non existent since it was only 200 francs less expensive than the big apartment in the same building I left. There was more light. The disadvantages were; extremely hot in summer on the top floor, 16 degrees in the winter due to faulty heating, noise through cardboard thin walls from the next door neighbors, the shame of not wanting to let people know that I lived in such a tiny place. A kitchen and bathroom without windows. The kitchen was so small you could touch all four walls by simply stretching your arms out. The bathroom was small and grotty. There was only one room although of a decent size (4.5 x 5 meters). . Watching this programme I feel so sorry for the occupants of the tiny apartments. Every day I entered my ex small apartment I tried to feel grateful for having a clean and safe place to live and conceptualized it as a hotel suite. I think that every person and family should have the right to affordable decent housing because if you don't have that it seriously infringes on human dignity, psychological health and people's social lives perhaps even their physical health.

Also, considering the immense demand for living space the prices would still be extremely high even with more space. I'm not surprised when all of the media fail to recognise that around 50% of HK's population lives in public housing and subsidised housing, which has an area of around 300 sq. ft. on average, and monthly rental of public housing ranges from US$300 - US$500.  Fun fact, the intro of your video is one of the most famous public housing establishments names Choi Hung Estate, that rents for US$300-500, and you still managed to ignore it right in front of you.   This is one of those phenomenon where one poorly researched and misinformed reports went viral, and nobody does anything about it once they have reached the intended moral high ground.   Now I'm not going to deny "private housing" is expensive in HK, but the situation is extremely over exaggerated. Why would you include the income of the 50% population who lives in public housing into the calculation, when they don't even live in private housing properties?   The cage houses on the other hand is in fact a problem, but these residents have also made a choice of not living in public housing because these cage houses are usually located in district centres. A lot of them sacrifice space and comfort for conveniences. Now there are a number of people who are waiting in line for public housing, and the line is getting longer and should be addressed, but this is not unlike any social problems all over the world, such as poverty, homelessness, drug abuse etc. But please don't relate cage housing with expensive living costs. You're comparing apples and oranges.

Not sure how accurate it is to say there is plenty of developable land in HK. Already most new housing is being dug into the mountain sides or built on reclaimed land that used to be ocean. In fact, nearly all new large scale developments are on reclaimed land - the only areas where there is sufficient land to build upon at any major scale. More than half of the buildings you see on your classic pictures of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon are on reclaimed land, and more than 20% of the population live on reclaimed land. If there is truly easy-to-build space in Hong Kong on natural land, you can bet there would never have been such a push to create so much reclaimed land.

It's convenience cost. A guy who had lived in USA since he was 7. He came back to HK 20 years later. I told him get the hotel little bit far such as 20 minute bus distance.  He said he'll no. Notice, he got used to commute long hour in Los Angeles. 20 minute bus distance in LA nothing,  but 20 minutes to HK downtown is not ok. Yes, bus in LA runs every hour, but bus in suburbs HK runs every 10 minutes. People get used to convenience. HK is small, but people can find cheaper n better housing in New Territory. Yes, when I visited HK, I stayed in a hotel in New Territory, the one I recommended my friend to go. The room was bigger, and hotel cost was cheaper. Getting to restaurants,  shopping centers,  residential area without cars was easier than any places in LA. The problem is after that 20 minutes to downtown,  you still have to catch buses, subway, taxi. He just did not want to spend that time. Yes, he commutes a lot in LA, but he couldn't stand that commute time in Hak. I guess that is Hker mentality.  Me, living in LA without car for 4 decades,  if I had to live in HK, I would pick cheapest n comfortable housing.  It may take 90 minutes n one train and 2 buses. Still better than LA

I'm staying with family now but before the coronavirus I used to live in various rooming houses throughout Durham, North carolina. Though there was some differences in the different places that I stayed quite often the room with nothing more than 8x12. You had room for a bed, a television at the end of the bed, a very small closet and a dresser. Then whatever you needed to place on the dresser. I bought a small mountable TV and that gave me some space but for the most part I was in a prison cell. These rooms in the last place that I stayed were in the basement so there was no natural light in the rooms. Not only that but these places cost around $125 a week so a total of $500 every 28 days. This is a really common way to live in the hood and when I leave my family's house I'll probably have to go back to living that way because Durham has become a very trendy place to live and all of downtown has been taken over by modern and expensive living situations. The hood neighborhood that I used to stay in was actually whitewashed and now there are no old houses that you can subdivide so you have to go into whatever neighborhoods, which get worse each time you're forced to move down. Tons of crime. Tons of drugs and prostitution and only grocery stores instead of supermarkets to buy your food stuffs, without having to get on a bus for a long ride and then carry your groceries back. That's the way poor people live in this country but nobody ever talks about it.

Not tryna justify the living space, but kids in Hong Kong will have a better social life than rural dwellers. Because in the countryside, the only way to get anywhere is by car, but in a city like Hong Kong, every local street has shops, playgrounds, plus short walking distances to school. This means that most of their childhood will be spent outside, in a quite enjoyable neighbourhood as well. In these extreme cases it is not so good, but in general Hong Kong is better than rural America for children.

Â @thetimelapseguy8Â  The fact that things are so far apart is exactly why rural America is better for children. You canâ€™t go to the movies every weekend because itâ€™s a 30 minute drive, so instead you go out in the woods and play hide and seek. I spent so much of my childhood outside or at the park. Also, the towns are small and very tight knit so you grow up with people and have lots of very close friends. I wouldnâ€™t choose to be born in a overpopulated city when I could live in the middle of nowhere with fresh air and good people. Tons of respect to those who live in cities, but I definitely prefer the small town life lol

â€‹Â @user-jj6xp2ln4dÂ  I live in a 600 year old town of 2000 people, and it's great! I know I am late to the party, however, I have an idea to alleviate the issue. If housing businesses are profiting from housing, and the government is relying on income from housing and land deals, what if the government built it's own high density housing. They already own the land and it would be a direct income rather than taking some income from businesses. The government could offer this housing at a cheaper price to increase the amount of money a citizen saves. This would allow the citizens to spend more of their money within the market. However, due to low taxes on goods and services in Hong Kong, I do not know what the long term effect that lowered housing costs would have on the cities overall economy.

It seems that the people here did not understand. The Hong Kong government does not put market interests before people's basic needs; they put their own interest before people's needs. Hong Kong is so dense precisely because of its free market policy and low taxes - it attracts people there - most people's jobs and income depend on this policy because companies depend on it. But politicians want money anywhere, so they keep these people in that situation because it is profitable for them. Raising taxes would be unemploying people to give politicians more money.

When I hear someone saying this is fault of greedy land hoarders my first thought is that they know nothing about the land issue in Hong Kong. To begin with around 30% of the housing in Hong Kong is provided by the state as a public matter and another 15% is subsidized, so it's not even run for profit on almost half of the industry, so saying the issue is due to companies running for profit is a huge misunderstandment. Plus Hong Kong's main issue isn't "The rich hoarding land to bump up prices", which doesn't mean it's certain part of the issue, but the government is the main reason. Some causes of high housing prices caused by the state: -Small House Policy -People's Liberation Army usage -Brownfield sites Without counting that an important part of the revenue from the Hong Kong government comes from housing. Then the reasons that can't be directly controlled by neither government nor the businesses: -Land scarcity -High demand; at least partly because of immigration of Chinese people (Around 150 a day) Then, causes of high prices due to private organizations: -Rural land hoarding But this is false because it's no longer an issue. The government seized 7.3 million square feet of land of these kind So the only and single currently land issue created by private organizations is the construction of private recreational spaces which take up space that could be used for housing. So before saying "But, all in Hong Kong is run for profit and that's the issue with land" remember that the industry you're talking about is curiously the most intervened one, while prices for other goods and services produced by much more deregulated industries are accessible in comparison to wages.

HK is that great economically libertarian experiment UK (and now China) never dared back home but that reaps in the wealth growth. Tax only small amounts to the upper 20% -and the result is the worlds freest economy, and also the worlds largest wealth gap of any OECD territory, and second only to NYC as the world's most divided city. Despite that 10%  of the population are now millionaires, high life expectancy, great infrastructure, healthcare and schooling a whopping 78% remain working class and 100,000 effectively homeless living on the streets, cage/ coffin homes and rooftops. Even across the border in urban China it's 75% middle class (and by comparison 50% middle class in US). The HK poverty line is set at only $5,000 a year (in the world's most expensive city), yet 1/5 fall into it. In any other city, unconstrained by being a small colonial island without British/ Chinese passports and confucianist society, life would have devolved long ago into crime, favelas and the rich fleeing. 1/3 of seniors struggle for their most basic nutrition and 1/5 of schoolkids miss a meal.

The solution doesn't make sense. The wellbeing of the market, in many cases especially in Hong Kong, equals the wellbeing of the people. If the government increases taxes, it will be less attractive to businesses, which will lead to fewer jobs and less money overall. While it will make real estate less competitive, it will make the people poorer. In addition, considering Vox supports solving climate change and all, expanding the urban area further would lead to deforestation and increased carbon emissions, as more people drive cars, more industries open up, and each family unit takes up larger square footage. Hence, the solution you presented will come with major consequences for Hong Kong. A better solution would be the one you dismissed, building better architecture - taller buildings that utilize the available land efficiently. This solution does not require major policy changes, and it will actually attract more real estate developers to Hong Kong. This solution is entirely feasible considering the city's incredibly competitive economy. It's a win-win.

Not really, around 30% of the housing in Hong Kong is provided by the state as a public matter and another 15% is subsidized, so it's not even run for profit on almost half of the industry, so saying the issue is due to companies running for profit is a huge misunderstandment. Plus Hong Kong's main issue isn't "The rich hoarding land to bump up prices", which doesn't mean it's certain part of the issue, but the government is the main reason. Some causes of high housing prices caused by the state: -Small House Policy -People's Liberation Army usage -Brownfield sites Without counting that an important part of the revenue from the Hong Kong government comes from housing. Then the reasons that can't be directly controlled by neither government nor the businesses: -Land scarcity -High demand; at least partly because of immigration of Chinese people (Around 150 a day) Then, causes of high prices due to private organizations: -Rural land hoarding But this is false because it's no longer an issue. The government seized 7.3 million square feet of land of these kind So the only and single currently land issue created by private organizations is the construction of private recreational spaces which take up space that could be used for housing. So before saying "But, all in Hong Kong is run for profit and that's the issue with land" remember that the industry you're talking about is curiously the most intervened one, while prices for other goods and services produced by much more deregulated industries are accessible in comparison to wages.

Economic freedom doesn't have anything to do with the price of living or taxes. Basically, the more "economically free" an economy is, the more capitalist it is. To be economically free, a country must have little to no restrictions on trade and prices. In layman's terms, the government doesn't place limits on how high or low prices can be, which means they can be very very cheap, or in Singapore and Hong Kong's case, very very expensive. Taxes are not considered economic restrictions, so a country can have very high taxes but be economically free at the same time.

Thank you for the video. I always enjoy watching them. You do an excellent job.  Unless I'm missing something, it seems that that your final statement in the film regarding the necessity of the government putting the interest of its people above the interest of the market is not a proper conclusion based on the film's claims. I understand that Hong Kong's market claims to be the freest in the world. However, whatever index is used to calculate that is clearly overlooking the huge restrictive market effect of the government owning virtually 100% of real estate. That is definitely not a truly free market. I'm sure that there are thousands of investors ready to develop much more hygienic and humanistic housing projects if the government would simply be willing to lease more land or sell land. The issue is not that the government leases land (although that is odd), it's that it leases so little of it. Were the government to free up the land for more use, enterprising individuals would quickly develop more housing for the incredible demand. (The people desperately need it!)  In my opinion, this is an example of the effect of unhelpful government land restrictions, not a government that over-emphasizes the interests of the market. They are clearly overlooking the interest of the market (AND their poor citizens) by not letting the other land be developed. Obviously, not all the land should be developed, green spaces must be maintained, and smart environmental regulations must also be enforced. Freeing more land for development would benefit the market (more business), the people (more space! Have mercy!), and the government (more money, whether through income/sales tax or land leasing).  Overall, seems like a very silly and destructive use of land by Hong Kong.

I know I was supposed to be distracted by the appalling HK living conditions you revealed, and moved to signal my virtue by commenting only on that. I wasn't, and I won't. The conditions are very sad indeed, but I'm strongly moved to say that I missed your explanation of WHY, paraphrasing you, "government has no incentive to free up more land". I think this is precisely the reason why people in Hong Kong are protesting. Democracy is just an excuse, but the underlying reason is that people are miserable, they need to vent out their anger. The story behind unaffordable housing in Hong Kong starts a century ago when the British colonized Hong Kong and owned practically all the land. After the British left, the Hong Kong government inherited this seemingly unsustainable practice of land selling instead of increased taxation. The rise in land prices is good for both the government which they can get more funding and real estate moguls which they can maximize their profits. This would also be potentially good for the population in which they see their real estate property values go up. It seems to be a win-win-win scenario for everyone. This would all be under the premise that the population can all get well-paying jobs and afford the places. Ever since the recent two decades of globalization, there is a huge gap between the rich and the poor. The majority of the population are not getting well-paying jobs. Even though Hong Kong is one of the financial centers of the world, but not everyone will be in lucrative industries such as finance or technology. As a result, common people are not able to afford housing while the rich are getting mega-rich. It really is a pretty sad reality and it seems like this is becoming more and more of a norm across the world.

I see Westerners having houses with actual kitchens and a staircase with a backyard and a driveway. Meanwhile I'm living in a crammed apartment (rented, I've never lived in property that was actually owned by my family, unlike a lot of you) with 6 people, a bedroom for my sister and I (bunk bed) where there is barely space to walk, a bedroom for my parents, a living room where the TV is 2 meters away from the sofa, another bunk bed in the living room for my auntie and grandpa. And God forbid anyone ever has to be in our kitchen and bathroom. You'd probably cry if you had claustrophobia. We don't even have a bathtub. It's just a square space in the corner. And I'm considered LUCKY in Hong Kong. It just breaks me how we'd be able to afford and live in houses with two floors and a kitchen with a table and everything the common Westerner has. But we can't, because we settled here and we can't just start a new life. Be grateful you even have a mirror in your bathroom.

My step-dads mother grew up in a village island in the Hong Kong bay for her whole childhood. Though, when she was 7, some Hong Kong business men bought the island & tore the village down to build condos. They never had a say, they were all given condos to live in & to this day there's still one there for family use but, her & everyone else's way of life was torn away. They were self sustainable, everyone knew each other, but then the took that away. They then put in a big ferry to get to the mainland & outlawed the use of their boats. She immigrated to Winnipeg, Manitoba with her husband after that. They moved back to Hong Kong & to Canada throughout my step-dads life but ultimately stayed in Canada.   My belief is that housing should be free, people shouldn't have the right to take it away like that & nobody deserves to live in such confined spaces. Unless I guess they actually wanted to, not that they were basically forced to.

in 2010 the town where my grandparents lived collapsed. there was an earthquake or something like that and everything was destroyed. the government gave "houses" to all the people while building another town. the houses were 6Ã—9 meters and all together, we could hear the people in the other houses speak, move, go to the bathroom. we were 11 people in that "house": my grandparents, my mom, my brother, my aunt, her husband and their four kids -and me. as horrible as it seems (and felt for the first months) we got used to that style of living. I don't even know how, I was like 12 and my memories are blurry, but we lived like that for five years. now that we have a proper house, with separate rooms, a garden, even stairs, I can't believe we lived in that tiny boxes for so long. but, believe me, when a tiny space smaller than a garage is all you have, yo get used to that.

Land is finite. It doesn't matter if you were in peak USSR Moscow, Ancient Egypt Tanis, "peak" Athens, current Pyongyang, London, La Paz or Hong Kong. You won't be solving any housing problems without more land to allocate citizens (unless you force people to stop having children and ban immigrants, then yeah, in a few decades you would see some improvement).   The thing is that the "free" market approach made HK overly attractive and they never had a large territory to begin with, so a housing problem was inevitable. But if HK had more area, people could live a bit further from the city and have more comfort while paying less money.  "Oh but then people would live too far from their workplaces" mhm yeah. My point is that you will never easily please everybody. Transportation issues are generally lessened by new technologies or local governments stimulating companies, but it's just too complex.   Anyway, HK's issue is not capitalism nor lack of capitalism. Even a planned economy would struggle allocating 7 million citizens if it had only 1000kmÂ² to work with.

Jeremy Lam yes actually Hong Kong is part of China. Itâ€™s called One Country, Two Systems. Hong Kong is a Special Administrative Region of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China. So yes, Hong Kong has separate policies and laws from the mainland and they have their own currency. People coming from mainland China to Hong Kong have to show a passport and Hong Kong citizens travel on separate passport from mainland citizens. However, with that said, it still is part of China and there still are certain rules and conditions from China that they have to follow. One being that all land in Hong Kong belongs to the mainland except for one church. Currently though, China is trying to abolish the current One Country Two Systems policy and make Hong Kong completely part of China sadly. There has been a lot of violence and human rights violations from China in Hong Kong during the last little while. China has removed all pro-democracy books from Hong Kong libraries now. Nobody deserves a free ride, but in the lottery of life some people just have bad luck, and are born with or destined to suffer health complications that impede their ability to work, or through no fault of their own have the misfortune to experience any number of other complications in life. Â @DrunKaoÂ  whats a pedantist?

Â @fuckoffhackers8619Â  Â austin sellersÂ  a person being pedantic.  Being pedantic is when you go out of your way to take someone literally by their word at the expense of the point they are trying to make and correcting or pointing out peoples typos or grammatical errors   Instead of commenting on what they were trying to say, you comment on what they did say, to make yourself seem smarter.  For an example: "pugs are a very unhealthy dog breed and by purchasing one your contributing to the problem."  Instead of making a retort and productively engaging in the discussion, they'll simply point out the grammatical error in your statement. I.e; by commenting "*you're" because in the previous statement you had the misfortune of typing:  [pugs are a very unhealthy dog breed and by purchasing one {YOUR} contributing to the problem.]  Instead of [pugs are a very unhealthy dog breed and by purchasing one {YOU'RE} contributing to the problem.]  Being pedantic unironically only serves to derail discussions and insult the other person's intelligence.  It's usually a form of anti-social behavior and a sign of below average intelligence.   Because if you use your common sense and critical thinking it would be obvious that the original poster said "government live in these conditions", the original poster obviously meant "people in government living in these conditions" or politicians rather than normal people working in government.  You'd be better off commenting on what's obvious that the person is trying to say rather than correcting them.

You know they justify these smaller and smaller homes by saying that "people want to live simpler" and smaller I guess. And that is true. If you look at it from the perspective of economic theory. The law of supply and demand. There is a huge demand even for small apartments. So therefor, in economic terms "it must be what people want." I think this is a brilliant showcase demonstrating the flaws of economic thinking in the first place. A lot of our modern world has been designed by economists with flawed theories. Perhaps we should've listened to psychologists, anthropologists, sociologists and other experts as well. They could've been able to explain the other side. Just because there is a demand for something, doesn't mean that that should be the only driving mechanism in a society. Perhaps the government should've regulated the minimum size for living conditions thus forcing companies to build taller or more houses so that everyone can fit, rather than smaller.

Due to immediate circumstances  I had to find a place for me and my few month baby. A shelter let's you stay 60 days max around here. I got part time bakery job only 2 days week for 12 hours making barely anything but I could take my child to work. After I ran out of shelter time and still couldn't get a place I ended up in a hallway.  The women had 1 bedroom 1 bath apart on second floor of duplex for 9 people. The hall where you walk in before going upstairs to apartment had enough space for cot, crib right beside, and mini fridge end of bed for $50. I did that for months. No privacy was hardest breastfeeding. You do what you have to do. In the end I choose my husband solely based on the fact I had halfway home in exchange as taking care of his elderly mother. It got me off the edge at least. Been 11 years and life is ok. Finally getting our lives on right path.  Good luck out there.
Â @sjfinley8002Â  I'm so glad u are doing better now..u are stronger than I am

Â @pumpkinpopupsÂ  Thank you. I'm not sure I'm stronger, I just made hard decisions. Keep living and struggling or take an offer. He is not cruel or mean but you are not first priority,  there is no love, he will not help you much such as childrearing,  etc. But I was mentally ok enough to say yes. I said yes to stable roof over my head and house stability for childrearing, responsiblity to enable me to have food and pay bills the best we could, and security that really nothing will change unless I choose. My children are number one, I live for them, once they are gone I will move on and struggle but never look back. I am at halfway mark and ok. I wish there was more finances for more meals for myself or to fix the property or even have anything to save but it's not possible. Minimum wage don't go far. I settled for my children but I see the light at the end of the tunnel when I can move on and make my life for myself for once. I'm halfway there! I won't give up on that possibility of freedom. I pick the rose with the thorns.   I hope you find your way and never give up.

But major developers, including Henderson Land, New World Development and Sun Hung Kai Properties , are sitting on "no less than 1,000 hectares" of agricultural land, according to government estimates. None of the three developers would clarify exactly how much rural land they hold, either directly or through shell companies. Two declined to comment on their plans for it or why they were sitting on the land.  Sun Hung Kai said it has been working to convert its agricultural land for "appropriate developments to help address the shortage of developable land and housing in Hong Kong", but offered no examples.  Holding on to the land until it is rezoned for private development is potentially lucrative. Property prices have more than doubled in the last decade, and many city centre private flats sell for at least $25,000 per square foot.

Lacking of living space is the the most serious problem in HongKong right now, and itâ€™s the hardest problem to be solved by the government. On the surface, government owns the other 75% of land in HongKong, the problem seems mainly comes from the government that wasnâ€™t willing to develop the land, however, the government wanted to solve the problem since right after HongKongâ€™s returning to China in 1997. HongKong has been served by four chief executives since returning to China. The first executive, , Mr Tung Chee-hwa, has proposed a policy address regarding the living space problem, called the 85,000 Housing Project, which means government will help to increase not less than 85,000 residential units a year. He hope that 70% of the households in Hong Kong can buy their own homes in 10 years. The average waiting time for public rental housing will be reduced from 6.5 years to 3 years. From 1997- 1999, the government sold a lot of land for the construction of residential. After the year 2000, the first batch of units built during the "85,000" project were launched, and 85,710 residential units were completed. In 2001, the total number of residential units were increased to 100,000. The ironic part is, Hong Kong's economy is heavily controlled by real estate developers. Before Hong Kong was handed over to China by the British, The Sino-British Joint Declaration limits the amount of land sold in Hong Kong each year, so that the colonial government will not sell the most important land resources of Hong Kong before the transfer of sovereignty, and then take the fiscal reserves away. In this context, Hong Kong's demand for real estate has continued to rise due to continued economic growth. However, Hong Kong's land supply has not increased. This historical issue resulted a bubble economy in the 1990s. Many people get rich by speculating on stocks and real estate. The financial industry and the real estate industry have become important pillars of Hong Kong's economy. According to statistics, the overall property price in Hong Kong increased by 68% within 3 years and 10 months in the peak period from January 1994 to October 1997. However, due to Mr. Tungâ€™s 85,000 Housing Project in 1997, huge amount of housing supply destroyed the real estate market. Coupled with the Asian financial turmoil, it caused Hong Kong property prices to plummet. The majority of private properties have depreciated by 70% in about five years. Many middle classes have become negative assets and Hong Kong's economy is in a slump. The "85,000" policy became one of the most criticized policies of Tung Chee-hwa. At that time, many people thought that the "85,000 Housing Project" was the culprit in the decline in property prices. People hope that the Government will amend this policy to curb the fall in property prices. As a result, on July 1, 2003, about 500,000 people in Hong Kong held the largest anti-government demonstrations on the basis of against 23 legislation. Although Beijing has repeatedly indicated that it supports the Hong Kong government headed by Tung Chee-hwa, but one year later, on July 1, 530,000. People (FNL data) held anti-government demonstrations again. Since then, under the pressure of Hong Kong people, medias and the business community, in 2005, Tung Chee-hwa announced his resignation on the grounds of physical discomfort. After all these things happened, successive Hong Kong government has become very cautious to increase supply and lower housing prices. Since the early 2000s, the Hong Kong SAR Government has implemented a number of measures to reduce the supply of housing, resulting in a significant reduction in the number of newly built public and private housing. By February 2011, Hong Kongâ€™s overall residential property prices have surpassed the previous highs of October 1997. Some newspapers pointed out that the rent of property prices has risen sharply, the public grievances have increased, and people's livelihood has been greatly affected. In 2011, the middle class found that they could not buy a house because the price was too expensive. In 2012, people began to think that Tung Chee-hwaâ€™s "85,000 project" was correct. If there were no 85,000 in the same year, young people in Hong Kong can only live in cage homes and subdivided units. How to deal with this ambivalent problem? Itâ€™s a very difficult challenge for the Hong Kong government.

Mimosa Kokko Hong Kong isnâ€™t part of China. China and Japan may be over crowded in some places but they have very rural areas with not many people as well. China has a problem with famine in the past as well as lack of access to birth control, but wages and ability to travel are the biggest problems currently so many people are moving into tightly packed cities because they canâ€™t travel to work if they live outside of it. Japan has the highest rate of terminal villages in the world, meaning the vast majority of people living there (I believe itâ€™s if 70% of the people there) are over 60 years old, aka theyâ€™re getting old and passing away naturally so those villages are disappearing but the land availability is still there, itâ€™s just not in the cities. Thatâ€™s the issues with most places like this, itâ€™s far to expensive to live in a city but people either want to live near their work or donâ€™t have a way to get to their work if theyâ€™re not within walking distance. Hong Kong is a former British colony and independent province existing in China. The protest (or civil war) that is being waged currently across the city is reflective of the exact debate you are all having above; Beijing ultimately wants to see Hong Kong fall in line as a full-fledged administrative region of China.    Some of you are saying 'China is a messed up place' and including Hong Kong in that statement, but if you had visited there just a year ago, you would have found a clean, safe, cosmopolitan society with excellent living standards and as much freedom of autonomy afforded to its citizens as those in the US. It was a hub of business, food, consultancy, trade and liberty.   Those who live in mainland China do not understand the ongoing protests. They have never lived with the same freedom of oppression that those in Hong Kong enjoy. Therefore, there is overwhelming pressure from citizens of the mainland to see their Hong Kong brothers join the fold, to maintain the peace. Whereas those in Hong Kong have witnessed the (sometimes brutal) regime of mainland China and want to protect their freedom.   Unfortunately, this is all pointing towards an explosive finish. The protesters in Hong Kong will never give in. They were protected throughout the cultural revolution and they didn't see their ideological leaders executed. Their backbones are still very much in tact.  But, when it comes to this Chinese government, if you won't bow, they you must break. We may be headed towards a repeat of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

Thanks for the interest in this topics, but some corrections. Hong Kong government doesnâ€™t own all lands here, many villagers own most of the lands in the New Territories. I am now a resident of the United States.. Originally from Mumbai, India, home to one of world's largest slum locality... Although I was fortunate enough to be born and raised in a 2 bedroom apartment, not everyone was.... Right through my schooling through college days and then work life... I saw people struggle it out in local trains packed with people, trying to make ends meet, to get a home for themselves and a decent living... Over the past decade and a half, owning homes in the suburbs has become an increasingly herculean task.. The city is far out of limits of the middle class and is only something that the super rich can afford... Growing up, I always heard of the economic success of China and its regions being at par with the west and how they worked the miracle over the decades with persistent hard work.. However, this documentary speaks of the other side... Seemingly, the middle class slogged to make the rich richer and as the country's economy grew, so did the disparity and rich-poor gap... I have always admired the west for their consistent and equality for all that they have always advocated and realized... Here, you cannot find such poor quality housing areas, ghettos or pockets in any cities across the country.. While there is a grave problem of homelessness in major cities, it mostly can be attributed to drug abuse... Aside from that, every person who works a 9- 5 job is guaranteed a decent home if not the best.... You simply can't have to many people crammed in small rooms unless you want to create a law and order issue and end up on the wrong side of it...

Â @jerrykwon8837Â   By "house" did you mean "home"? With respect, while those 2 words are frequently used interchangeably they have very different meanings. A house only refers to a building that is usually at most only 1 or 2 floors high that is not a tower or skyscraper. Most houses are built to have enough space to hold one family comfortably inside them. Like a mansion would be a house but even a luxury condo would not be a house.  A home can be anywhere that a person lives (house, condo, apartment, factory dormitory, boat, cave, etcetera.)  Housing is a word thats used mostly by governments to describe how many places there are for people to live within a given region (like the government of the city of Vancouver might discuss how the city needs more affordable housing in order for the city's citizens to have afforable places to live.)

When I did as-built surveys for architecture firms in San Francisco I was sometimes in an empty mid-rise building next to a high-density residential building in Chinatown. From my vantage point I looked across a small alley at several floors of tiny rooms inhabited by one person, using a middle-aged man. In that tiny room would be all his belongings, usually set out without efficient storage shelves or cabinets. Overhead a bare bulb. Restroom down the hall, to be shared by many other room tenants. I saw this and thought "How can anyone live in that manner?" It was sad but this was what people accepted as their lot.

A few facts.  In 1995 when the Brits still controls hk, hk's housing bubble peaks, and every hker was hoping that mainlanders would move in in 1997 and buy their overpriced second-hand houses, and financial crisis came in 1997, the bubble broke, the mainlanders didn't come, the first ever chief executive of hk Tung cheehwa published his 85000 housing unit per year plan, the real estate price dropped. The furious HKers who spent all their money on houses protested due to negative equity. Then Suen mingyeung's 10 tricks came and brought the housing price back and HKers went to protest again. Hk's HOS program which builds flats for lower income residents was not resumed until late 2011 under the pressure of PRC government.  The current land management system under which the government owns the land was introduced in 19th century under British rule. Â Â  Wow. There is a lot to unpack there. First, nobody cares about what you "feel". Tell us what you think. That's more powerful. Second, it is impossible for white people to uproot current tenants. Most of the white people are moving to the neighborhood for the same reason the current residents did. They can't afford to live elsewhere, because they work for a living too and have been priced out of their old neighborhoods by "white" people. Third, is the neighborhood really established by the current tenants? If the current residents own the houses they live in, then who can raise the rent, therefor pricing them out?  The property owner raises the rent, not the white people "coming in". Fourth, when white people move OUT of the city it's criticized as "White Flight". When white people move IN, it's criticized as "Gentrification". So what would you like them to do? Fifth, this really comes down to ownership. White people that don't own are going through a unique problem. They are constantly being priced out of their homes by wealthier people of all skin colors and forced to move to the next cheapest neighborhood where they are not welcome. The problem is the population that needs it vastly outweigh the market supply, and with the cost of land being extremely expensive in all but a handful of areas in the country (new territories is the only place where land is somewhat cheaper) the available land is often purchased by Private property developers as they can sell these apartments at insanely high prices to the affulent/high saving/expat market which makes up a large bulk of hk's professional workforce.  Another thing to note, salaries for menial/physical jobs are quite low in HK, making getting on the private ladder quite hard unless you're saving everything and have a partner doing the same. However, if you're willing to put up with travelling then you can get cheaper private accommodation outside of HK island and the main areas of Kowloon. Places such as Sha Tau Kok are fairly cheap at around Â£7-800 PCM for a three bedroom house.  However, if for some reason you don't have a great family structure in place, and find it hard to hold down a job (alot of cage home occupants have/have-had drug issues and other things that prevent them from maintaining a steady income) then even this aformentioned affordable rent isnt doable - and depending on your circumstances, your chances of getting a government apartment could be slim... Hence where these cage homes come in and exploit the gap in market

Â @tommytam6433Â  Wow!  Thanks for the information.  That sounds as if it is not going to end well!

Â @AmidatÂ  - Cage spaces started in the 50s/60s as a result of a huge number of migrations from the mainland during the Chinese Civil War and a surge in birth rates in a successful economy.  The population increased from 2,015,300 in 1951 to 3,129,648 in 1961. In response the HK Gov. started building housing estates; however, the response could not keep up with the surge.  Cage homes became popular among migrant workers, as the rental fee was low.  They had a choice.  They didn't have to be there.   These cages still exist as the HK Gov. has instituted a single-person scoring system for public housing and lowered public housing quotas. New immigrants are required to wait seven years to become Hong Kong permanent residents. Poor migrants are often forced to live in the cages until they receive a Hong Kong ID card.  (Information from Wikipedia)   In addition to migrants are tourists.  4.5 million in 2001 to 47.3 million in 2014, mainly from Mainland China, outnumbering tourists from all other countries combined.  In 2017, tourists rose to 58.47 million, 44.45 million from Mainland China, accounting for 76% of the total.  (Information from Forbes)   So, what are the lessons here:  (1) We live in the days of the internet.  So easy to research information before you rattle off with half-true innuendos designed to demean a group.  It appears there are strong arguments that Hong Kong would be better off, if it were still under British jurisdiction, albeit the Chinese Government still grants it financial/commercial freedoms as a designated Special Administrative Region.  (2) An important lesson for those in the West, especially liberal politicians, because their culpability is great, about what will happen with open borders, and even uncurbed legal immigration.  Such an ugly scenario already showing its ugly head in North American western cities (sanctuary cities, such as Chicago, and cities such as San Francisco, Seattle, Vancouver, B. C.), except that in the West they litter the streets with their tents feces and drug needles.  No covered cage rooms for them.  I have always been flabbergast at the foolish British agreement to hand Hong Kong back to China. Hong Kong used to be the best place in the world for business.  Now it is the third best place.   So, you see there are multiple contributors to the introduction of cage "apartments,"  but the singular most significant cause is the infiltration of migrants from China and a city struggling under massive overpopulation.  Next time, do your homework and become a commentator with credibility.

More people should play the game Monopoly and understand the lessons it tries to teach.

Firstly, only fools, the greedy, and uninformed thought real estate (in whatever form)  was a safe bet with almost zero risk of losing money.  Astounding, because the real-estate downturn prior to the 2008 collapse occurred not that long ago in the 1980's - in recent living memory.  Always important to drill down to ultimate causes.  Causes of the housing issues today:  (1) Massive irresponsible population growth (that is exponential/geometric, not arithmetic).  People today, still argue that people should have the right to as many children as they want, especially if they are rich and can afford the children.  They give no thought to world-wide competition for the same limited resources on a finite planet.  (2) Dysfunctional, inept governments in collusion with greedy developers, because each floor of, say, a 90-floor condominium building, produces a massive flow of taxes to waste.  (3) Migrations to the West and the need for more and more housing to accommodate immigrants and migrants.  How many of those living in cage homes in Hong Kong migrated from Mainland China?  (4) The domino effect of increasing house prices and rents.  If that neighbor just sold his house for $1million, then I better get into the market quickly and ask for $1.5 million for my similar house.  If that landlord can charge $2,000 for a small bachelor apartment, then I had better increase the rents for my rental suites, etc.  (5)  The move from individually owned, real-estate development companies, to huge public owned companies, but more troubling off-market private-equity and limited partnerships.   Having said that, we are already at population saturation point.  For sustainable living, focus must be on birth control, greatly curbed legal immigration and an end to illegal immigration.  If, say, Canada, where migration from China is huge, continues it's open doors, then Canadian cities will be the massively overpopulated new Hong Kongs. New capitalistic forms of commerce and corporations have to be developed to allow for higher wages, corporate ownership and job security.  Education will have to be dragged into that mix.  Lower taxation will be essential.

In my opinion, the problem is firstly a lack of land and a conflict of interest between the Upper+middle and lower classes. As the video shows, most available land has already been developed, and although there are pockets of flat land up in the North, nobody wants to live there because its far from the urban center and property values aren't as good there...which brings me to the second point.  Unlike other places in the world, many Hong Kongers see their home as an "investment" which they expect to appreciate in value. This brings us to the conflict of interest point. The lower classes, who cannot afford homes, want property prices to go down. Yet they still yearn to own their own place, yes, to live, but to also have a piece of investment that will pull them out of the lower income bracket to the middle class, hence the unwillingness to buy places in cheap, affordable, but subprime regions such as the New Terrioties, Lantau, and surrounding HK islands. Demand is high, supply is low, and prices keep rising.   The middle class, who often own land, want their home prices to continue going up as 1. a safety net, 2. an ability to earn extra (and i mean a lllooott) of money on the side 3. jump up a social ladder to go from lower-middle to upper-middle to even upper class. It is in their interest to keep supply low, demand high, and prices rising. Therefore they will veto and oppose to oblivion anything the government does to fix the situation, as their entire livelihoods essentially depends on their single apartment.   The rich in Hong Kong, especially the property developers, will also not allow prices to depreciate as it will affect their holdings as well, and make the land less appealing to invest in for the middle class. They want to stay rich. There goes any move to improve the situation from the upper class.   In my opinion, government change is only possible when they have the support of two of the three (lower, middle, upper) levels of society, regardless of numbers. Currently, the middle and upper class are happy with the status quo, and hence any hope for the situation to become better.

I wouldn't exactly call modern-day Hong Kong a "free market"; at least not to the extend at which they were after their UK-instilled constitution. China breathes down their necks, and it's already been made apparant that the government has total control over what small land is redistributed (and sold at "sky" high-prices to the wealthy). Bank/wealthy controlled, yet sanctioned by the government is crony-capitalism indeed, but is distinct from an actual free-market. In other words, it's a recipe for expensive land pricings. Not exactly a free market... albeit in name, sure. What I do wonder though, is whether or not more land development would increase the population (to match) over time. For the short while, prices should go down... but would the problem eventually worsen?
But my house rent is 7.400 hk dollars (7thousand 4 hundred) Mine is fine enough but we also have to pay for the rubbish fees 110 hk dollars

But you can't deny that HK has the most free market in the world and it definitely contribute a whole lot to the market price.  The important thing that didn't mentioned in the video is the speculation of housing in Hong Kong. After the government release their lands to the market, they do almost nothing to them because they respect the market and they aren't government property anymore. However, the land they release although are used to built housing by developers, they aren't really for housing, in fact no one can afford any of those flats. The people buying those flats are the rich people who own multiple property already, and they brought them for speculation, since HK housing price almost never drop, it's a guarantee gain. On top of this there are a lot of money coming from China to push the market price even higher.

In other words, more readily-available or cheaper land encourages population growth over time. Not like that's a bad thing outright, for a while it would help... but wouldn't it eventually just revert back and make things the same, but... bigger? Not trying to sound heartless or anything, I suppose it would depend. If people are willing to commute from more rural developments to urban hubs where there's work, maybe that would help alleviate the problem. Good luck finding parking though.

I'd like to comment on this as myself and my family have been battling for good housing for years. We live in one of the most expensive cities for rent in Europe: London. As you know, Hong Kong is an extreme example compared to London, but trust me we are also suffering with the wait for social housing...However, what I have seen in this report is really upsetting...I did not know that people were even allowed to leave in such horrendous conditions, especially the space. In the English capital, we are clearly in for a housing crisis, but the government has given us affordable 3-bedroom flats to live in. They consider the living space for a family of 5 (like mine) and while I share a bedroom with my sister, we accept what our government has given us as temporary accommodation, because we have the minimum required amount of space a decent human should have to live in (even though we have nowhere to put our laundry, we use our radiators and doors to dry the clothes... We have been waiting in the list for more than 10 years now for social permanent housing since 2007. We have also been evicted twice from different properties, not because we did not pay on time, but because our lease ended or the landlord wanted us out, it is very common in London, and often vulnerable families suffer a lot. It is a period of uncertainty but at least in Britain, our wellbeing and mental health is considered in housing. It is not as extreme and while I am very mad at the housing crisis going on in London and the amount of long time we have been waiting as homeless, looking now at Hong Kong made me realise that while I will probably never be able to afford to buy a house in London, people elsewhere such as Hong Kong have it way worse....I am so sorry. I really hope that justice is brought forward...for both of us...

You must be a terrible pessimist and cynic, assuming that every person out there making money only wants to do so by abusing and scamming everyone else. While corruption is a sad factor in any economy ever, the "Free market" is the best system mankind has discovered. The problem in this scenario is both poor management (as stated in the video) and the artificial scarcity created specifically for housing. With such a small percentage of the land allowed for housing (permitted by governmental policy) and the auction/leasing structure of the residential-zoned land, it creates scarcity in housing amongst such a huge population in a small geographic area. Think about the diamond industry. Diamonds are not rare, and turns out are very, very common. The Debeers Group only allows for a very, very small percentage of diamonds into the market at a time in order to keep scarcity high, even though many, many more diamonds are actually available. In this case the diamonds released into the market is the tiny amount of land released into the market. If all of the available diamonds were released right now, the diamond price would plummet and everyone could buy them at insanely low prices. If the Hong Kong government released a lot more land for residential zoning, it would create much more housing and the cost would dramatically lower due to the abundant supply.  What you have here is a basic population necessity being controlled by the government to create artificial scarcity.

But he lost in the end, because that killed that business, and others he had too. Because he didn't have capital left for the lean times. After spending all that money. He got no legal fees back in this so called "win". And that's the game they play to bully those that are smaller then them. They don't have all those lawyers to defend themselves. They use them to take people out basically.   He did force them to spend millions though, and there's a building in Providence RI that's not the shape it was originally designed to be, because of him. There's basically a corner section missing, and the building he leased is still there (they wanted to tear it down). He had to pay expert architect's to testify in court this would cost them over a million dollars to redesign the building, to prove their intentions. This cost him like $6000 a day plus expenses (he had to fly a guy in, and pay for food, and lodging, etc.).  So you're right. Our system is not fair. I don't know about yours unfortunately. But this was my whole point. There's no fairness in this country. He with the most money wins. Almost everytime too. That's why I laugh at the idea of a free market, at least in this country anyway. Pad 33Â  Dude, don't want it to come off as an insult but don't tell people to "get an education" when you yourself don't know what communism or socialism are. In communism the people own means of production themselves, and they don't pay for anything as value does not exist nor do classes, and there is no state either. In Hong Kong there are classes (you can clearly see economic disparities from people who live in holes and those who live in skyscrapers) a state (which even owns all of the land statally) value (goes without saying) and companies are 100% private, they're not worker-led or anything.  So while it certainly isn't Communist, it's actually far from being statist or authoritarian. The state doesn't have nationalized factories or such, it simply owns all the land because that's how it worked back in colonial states (like in America during colonization) and they just kept it when becoming indipendent.

There are 3 reason why this happened. Overpopulation, land problem and the government. This is what I learn from liberal studies class. Firstly, the population in HK are rising, but not because of birth problem, instead is immigrant. Many people from mainland come to HK for better education, working place, salary and e.t.c.  Second, the land problem in HK. HK isn't a big place. There's not much space for more buildings (There is once a land reclamation before). Third, the government help only the poor people also the immigrants. The people in the 'middle-class' can't get help from the government. Therefore, there are people who can't afford a flat (but they aren't too poor) and can't get help from the government. For instance, those people can't apply for public housing estate since they are above a line (I forget where that line is). In short, living in HK isn't easy. The competition in here is heavy which makes HK a stressful city.  Lastly, I'm just a secondary school student in HK. If I'm wrong, please correct me. Also, I don't know a lot in politics, so ya. I live in a short school bus tiny home in the U.S., about 70 square feet, and has/fits everything I need. In my opinion, it isn't necessarily the actual size/square footage of these Hong Kong homes that seems most dismal; It's the lack of sunlight and the fact that these cage houses are all piled on top of one another, whereas my bus-life feels more like living outside. Even if they can't afford anything else, it may not seem so bad if they live life outside, out and about, and only go home to sleep or shower. E.g. Sip coffee and eat breakfast while walking to work. Eat lunch at the park. Study or do homework at a cafÃ© or the library. Avoid T.V. Free yourself of clutter and adapt minimalism, etc. Certainly won't solve the problem at the core, but could make each day feel brighter.

I live in Hong Kong. Let me explain this.  Everyone had a choice, and they made theirs. No one forced them to live in those crammed spaces. There are neighborhoods in HK with much lower price/sq.ft. and better conditions. For 2000 HKD, instead of renting a cage, he could have pooled with 4 other people and share a decent apartment with beautiful interior in another neighborhood. Those people chose the cage because they think where they live is more convenient (not necessarily true) or have sentimental attachment to the neighborhood. Don't blame the government and the rising prices. Their choice is to blame. HK's housing is expensive, but the people who live in bad conditions only account for a tiny fraction of the population. There are less of them than homeless people in NYC. By the way, homelessness is not a problem in HK. (HK1000 people vs NYC 61000). Think about that. There is nothing wrong with the idea of HK being a place for free market economy. The average salary is extremely high compared to most other asian countries. It is the place to make money, have a good saving and live somewhere cheaper after retiring. Of course it's miserably expensive after they've stopped making money or don't have  income. Staying in HK with almost no income is obviously a bad choice.  Policy makers' job is to create policies to benefit the vast majority of people. They have done an excellent job. Look at the city of HK compared to the rest of asia (Japan excluded). It still serves as a role model for many neighboring developing countries. Keep in mind that the kind of poor people you saw in the video only account for a tiny fraction of the population. They had and still have the choice to move. HK is big, huge actually. It's not as dense and expensive as how the video portrays. The video makes a point, but it only tells a tiny part of the story.  Don't generalize from it.

Are you seriously suggesting those people in the videos are not minimalist enough... they literally live in a cage. No amount of decluttering can help with that. Hong Kong's problem is with land shortage - we barely have land to live on, let alone public spaces like parks. Vox neglected to mention all the "green areas" are located in remote areas far from where those people live. It isn't as easy as walking a block to a park.

Â @JiaRuAuÂ  Based on this video, you're right, most of them definitely seem pretty minimal. And I'm not pretending to understand how life really is for these people, as I've never visited Hong Kong, let alone lived there. I personally live in a space as small as many of these pictured and find it perfectly suitable, homey, and prefered; however, I know that I've freely chosen to live this way, whereas many of these people don't have a choice. For that, I feel lucky and grateful, and empathize with those in Hong Kong who are unhappy with their living situation. I guess the main point I was trying to make was that such minimal square footage of a living space doesn't seem to be as bad in itself, as the other conditions associated with it- like them being crammed together in tight dingy buildings without natural light, etc. Lots of people this day in age are all about "tiny homes," "vanlife," etc. and love their itty bitty spaces - but they likely spend most of their lives outside of these spaces anyway; outdoors, out and about, etc. If the people of Hong Kong are working 2-3 jobs to make ends meet, which unfortunately I'm sure most of them are, then I imagine they likely aren't spending much time in their "homes" anyway, and it is literally just a space to sleep and store a few belongings. Not saying they should just suck it up and be happy with it; everyone deserves to be comfortable at home. Just was pointing out what popped into my mind after watching this video.

It's often hard for people who are poorer to have a minimalistic lifestyle. HK is among the world's business and financial centres but by nature it's a hardly seen dot on maps.  Foreign investments means a lot to this mini piece of land.  Sources of income could hardly generate to a large scale if without foreign investments despite we are all along backed up by China with the supply of agricultural products and daily items at low expenses.   Low profit tax, low income tax and also its closeness to China makes HK appealing to foreign investors despite the payment of extremely high rents.  Great developers continued to dominate the property market and housing prices keep soaring high while the HK govt. depend heavily on land auction for its revenue and expenditure.   Housing policies brought down from governor to governor remained to be the vital criticism of the govt.  While living environment is congested and unsatisfactory, HK people pay low income tax and don't have the VAT.   Yet we have free education, free (for those in need)  or low medical expenses without making any contribution to medical insurance payment, free/subsidised home care services for the elderly and the disabled, free/subsidised pre-school education for day nursery, social security assistance and allowances etc.    Compulsory medical insurance by individuals was raised once or twice by the govt over the past years but was curbed by opposing voices.   There are pros and cons if we choose to stay here and at anywhere else while the govt. had the responsibility to make hk a better place to live especially for the low income groups.   But more important is to let youngsters see their future prospects.     The cake is there.   Cutting one bigger portion means smaller portions are left to the others unless the cake is enlarged.     The distribution of social benefits is the same.     The high train going between HK and Guangzhou South Station starts to operate from 23 Sept 2018.   It takes 50 mins to go from HK to GZ.    The establishment of the Guangdong-HK-Macau Bay Area aimed at the one-hour-living-circle (ä¸€å°æ™‚ç”Ÿæ´»åœˆ) which means travelling from one city to  another city within the bay area takes an hour only.    To solve HK's land shortage, there is suggestion that HK govt. can propose to China for leasing land nearby Macau for building flats for the hk people  and  HK law is to be applied within the leased territory. "Piece together an explanation for this trend" = it's simple, there is a huge influx of mainland chinese into hong kong. most Hong Kong land is protected from development. This has driven up the cost of limited real estate you can build on. They tried to fix this by building lots of cheap housing tenements on freed up land, but the long term hong kong locals complained (was bringing prices of their apartments down) so the plan was abandoned. So now it's back to building condominiums for the rich and installing chicken cages for everyone else. It's a catch 22-hong kong needs more low income buildings on undeveloped land, but developing undeveloped land in any way brings value of developed land next-door down. Hong Kong's rich don't want this. Meanwhile more and more low income people come to live and work in the city.

He tried to take a jab at Hong Kong for their low taxes, but horribly poor living conditions, but the reason they're having a housing crisis is a direct result of the fact that the authoritarian government owns all the land. If the land had been privatized, investors could have purchased the land long ago and began the long and arduous process of slowly developing the land out over decades. Now it's too late for that. The auctions drive the prices so ridiculously high that any investor that could afford to purchase use of the land for 50 years isn't going to want to waste that investment on housing.  I really enjoy Vox sometimes, but you can always tell they're looking to place blame toward capitalism when Hong Kong's problems are a result of a government wielding all the power and controlling all the land, as opposed to individual investors owning the land.

Having spent over a decade in the emergency services sector, all I could think about while watching this was the horror that would result from a fire in one of these cage/coffin home buildings.  Dividing up homes like this leads to a greater risk of death in a fire not just for the residents, but also for the rescue personnel who may become lost or trapped if these divided homes are not disclosed (as is often the case when a home is divided up illegally). High rises are built to meet certain fire and safety requirements and the number of units and maximum occupancy play an important role in all of this. If there are 4 families living in the space that was intended for 1 family and this situation exists in every apartment, imagine the sheer chaos during an emergency on just one floor of the building and how the increased number of individuals evacuating will slow that process to a crawl trying to fit X amount of people through an evacuation route designed for a quarter of that number.  Suffice to say, there are so many safety concerns with this situation that I canâ€™t even touch on them all without turning this into a complete diatribe.   Itâ€™s great that reform/change is happening, but these things often move at a snails pace until thereâ€™s a tragedy. As awful as it sounds, there are so many examples throughout history of tragedy being the catalyst for major change. However, it doesnâ€™t have to be that way, especially in circumstances like this one where the danger is evident to all.

The chart at the beginning is unsourced nonsense. I live in New York and have visited the other bottom 6 cities within the last two years, and (being a real estate agent) always check on the sales and rental rates wherever I go. From most expensive to least expensive rent theyâ€™d actually be ranked New York, London proper, LA, Toronto, Miami (I canâ€™t speak to the London suburbs). For purchase, from most to least expensive: London, New York, LA, Toronto, Miami. Like I said.... It's China, but it's not China.   As in all the other "independent" regions/districts a foreigner needs a passport to travel between them.  Citizens, mainland and/or regional, need to obtain a permit that expires.  It/they self govern, and that will not change based on strong-arm tactics from China.  Some of the "independent" regions have observer seats in the UN.  That's why I refer to the One-China policy, and say "it's part of China, but not China."  The same can be said about a few European city-state/state relationships. Catalonia and Spain being a recently politicized. Catalonia is a part of Spain, but is not Spain. You know, im not even a free market capitalism purest i actually tend to think more in terms of socialism and an economy that would be able to survive a global automation of jobs. But i can't help but think when watching this, that the government of Hong Kong is actually doing the correct thing here. If the goal here is to drive innovation through free marketplace of ideas, than reducing taxes and finding alternative revenue from corporations wanting an adress in a place that affords unfettered capitalism is exactly the way you preserve a city that can thrive in this aspect. The issue isnt the hoarding of land to increase its price, its actually the migration of people to Hong Kong who want to take advantage of its thriving marketplace. People are choosing to live in increasingly smaller places to take advantage of the economy and city structure. This choice is brought on by a need to forgoe ones basic necessities to achieve monetary gains that would allow one to survive  elsewhere. Its actually not Hong Kong that is at fault, its the rest of the world that is at fault. Our system of economics is beoken, abused, corupted and frail. It forces people into making choices like living in a place equivalent to a  parking space.

This is a demand problem far more than it is a supply problem. The economic opportunity in Hong Kong is so massive that people continue flooding in despite knowing they'll be living in a coffin apartment. Certainly there are people doing the bare minimum to survive, but most of those are due to personal choice. Lastly, I can assure you that the cage apartments are preferable to living in a Soviet Gulag. Capitalism will always be better for everyone than socialism. @OmegaTou I don't think this is an entirely accurate picture. While it is true that there is demand to live in Hong Kong, the population isn't growing very quickly. The annual population growth rate has only exceeded 1% once in the past two decades. For comparison, Australia, the country with the largest new houses in the world, has a growth rate that has exceeded 1% in all but one year in the same period. The difference between the housing markets of the two (a massive, mostly empty continent and a tiny pseudo-city state) is more in supply than demand. A more like comparison may be Singapore (self governing, highly commercial cities with similar densities), which has grown at a much faster pace than Hong Kong since the mid 1980's). I couldn't find data on average home size in general, but Singapore's public rentals are nearly twice as spacious as Hong Kong's. On a more qualitative note, I regularly hear about a housing crisis in Hong Kong and never hear about such problems in Singapore.

The policies mentioned in this video is the reaction to the small (~4%) build-able zoning area in Hong Kong. You don't want to have buildings on the mountains because they would require the trees and native eco systems to be removed, which can cause significant disasters (mud slides and alike) when a typhoon hits. When that happens, it's not just the houses built on the mountains that got washed away, all lives on the flat surface will suffer as well. I know this because my father worked for a government agency overseeing the housing development project proposals in the mountains and I have heard lots of examples of him receiving threats and bribe offers from the financial groups which eventually caused him to quit since he could no longer work in good conscience (it's either his life or all lives at the foot of the mounts that will be threatened because of the building proposal).   I am sure the community developers will not think like this and this video illustrated perfectly with the interviews from two urban development advocates. The basic rule applied here is that housing/building development does not consider long term safety, risks, and nature as high priority items. Most people want to be able to have a cheap place to live and that pressure can be high. However there is always a limit to everything. The nature does fight back pretty hard sometimes (e.g. superbug as a reaction to antibiotic abuse).

I am in-favor with your suggestion as to how the government of Hong-Kong should address this kind problem. This kind of reasoning and suggestions, however, are the very reason why our nature suffers. We often take our nature for granted because we regard it as a commodity rather than a part of our community that we should also nurture and, in recent environmental cases, must definitely preserve. Believe it or not, one of the possible solutions to this may be softening (if not slowly erasing) the Hong Kong-Mainland China border. Unlike any of the other cities that made the 0:19 list, Hong Kong don't really have a "greater area" or suburbs for less-than-high income groups to commute or move. In the case of New York, tons of people regularly commute from New Jersey to strike a balance between higher wages and lower living cost. Hong Kong doesn't have such an option right now. Also, Hong Kong is a great place to travel, but unless you really have 9-digit in the bank, don't think of working and living there. Almost the entirety of Hong Kong economy relies upon the stock market, real estate, and import-export, and there is practically no industry, no R&D, no natural resource for harvest, and few tech companies. The economic structure in Hong Kong fundamentally can't support good living condition for all of its 7+ million citizens, most people have to seek financial opportunities elsewhere, which means either going to another nation or move into mainland China.

I did the math on this. So the median price for a property is 19.7 times the median income according to the figures used here.   If a person started working at 20 years old, and earned median income for the entire work life, and the property bought also stayed at median price, and each month 1/3 of the gross income goes towards the mortgage, the loan itself will be repaid well after this worker's 70th birthday, but we haven't even considered interest yet. In this scenario, a lot of people would have to work 'til they drop, and still there may be outstanding payments. They could increase they share of their income they put towards the mortgage, but of course this would significantly impact on disposable income and their ability to save up.  This is why people in Hong Kong sarcastically say that they are slaving away their whole lives for a home (æ¨“å¥´).
Capitalism at its finest. There is no fix for all those troubles now.

The conclusion of this video is misleading. It's not a market failure causing this issue. The issue is market manipulation. Since the government owns all of the land, they have a monopoly over it, and so are able to price discriminate and centrally control quantity. In a well functioning market (which does imply many assumptions), the interests of the people are reflected in the market.
