They should model their housing after Singapore's HDBs. "HDB History and Towns The HDB story began with it taking over from its predecessor, the Singapore Improvement Trust. Persevering through challenges, HDB has since established public housing in Singapore as a benchmark of excellence.  Beginning Blueprint In 1960, there was a housing crisis in Singapore. Many people were living in unhygienic slums and crowded squatter settlements. Only 9% of Singaporeans lived in government flats, while others yearned for a place to call home.  The Housing & Development Board was thus set up on 1 February 1960, tasked to solve Singaporeâ€™s housing crisis.  HDB sprang into action, and in less than 3 years, it had built 21,000 flats; 2 years later, that number was 54,000. Within a brief span of 10 years, HDB built a sufficient number of flats for Singaporeans and resolved the housing crisis.   Supporting Pillars For HDB to successfully meet the difficult goals set out, it needed a sound public housing strategy. This strategy was defined by 3 crucial fundamentals:  The concept of a sole agency A sole agency in charge of public housing enabled more effective resource planning and allocation. This concept made it possible for us to secure the land, raw materials, and manpower for large-scale construction to optimise results and achieve economies of scale. A total approach to housing By adopting a total approach covering planning and design, land assembly, and construction, the housing task was carried out as a seamless whole â€“ through allocation, management, and maintenance. Strong government support Support from the government in the form of political and financial commitment, complemented by legislation, helped put early public housing on the right track quickly, which made housing the nation that much smoother and fruitful a journey. Landmark Housing HDB is now home to more than 80% of Singaporeâ€™s population, across 23 towns and 3 estates. Having completed more than 1 million flats and housed an entire nation, we believe there is more that we can do to build new-generation housing and smart, sustainable towns. We will continue to serve to the best of our abilities to create the best possible living environment where communities can thrive." https://www.hdb.gov.sg/

The British colonial authorities had the right idea regarding land ownership, sort of. Community ownership of land rather than private ownership of land is the right starting point, IF the members of a community embrace the principle that the earth is the birthright of all persons, equally. Nature is rightfully the commons for all to share. At the same time, everyone needs to have a secure access to some location on which to constructed a residential property or a business property. Again, the British authorities came up with the right approach by awarding access under a leasehold arrangement. However, to achieve both equity and economic efficiency, the leaseholds require specific characteristics that have not been adopted.  The economics are fairly straightforward. Every parcel or tract of land has some potential annual rental value. This value is created by actual and perceived locational advantages. Some advantages are created by nature directly (e.g., direct access to a harbor or other natural resources, or even a scenic view). Other advantages are created by the aggregate public and private investment in infrastructure and amenities. When leaseholds are awarded by competitive bidding, market forces will result in the full potential annual rental value coming to the public treasury. The terms of the ground lease must provide for periodic adjustment in the ground rent charges as the market ground rents rise (or fall).  Ideally, then, all buildings should be exempt from taxation. Buildings are private assets. They depreciate over time and require a constant infusion of funds for maintenance and systems replacement. This is consistent with Hong Kong's "free market" strategies. Selling the land of the community is not consistent with free market principles; selling land, or leasing it at below market ground rents distributes "rentier privilege" to those who hold land under these conditions.  Hong Kong's government has created a system that begins with a good idea but then creates a whole set of incentives and rules that have made it impossible for market forces to construct decent, affordable housing for many of its residents. Zoning should permit mixed-use development so that high rise buildings could contain commercial space on the ground floor, some office space on higher floors, and residential units on other floors. This can be accomplished and also provide land for parks and recreation. A combination of public collection of the full market ground rents and exemption of property improvements will do the rest.  Edward J. Dodson, M.L.A. United States of America

I did not mean to suggest that the British imperialists were humanitarians. I merely wanted to bring to light the fact that they hit upon (perhaps quite inadvertently) the idea that individuals should be required to lease land from the community and not be given fee simple ownership. Their system provided a good deal of revenue with which to pay for Hong Kong's infrastructure, saving the working people of the U.K. from being taxed for that purpose. However, the system was always suffered from political influence and special interests.

The explanation is very easy and is the same for pretty much all house price bubbles: excess credit. With regards to Hong Kong Citizen vs Long term resident: There is no such distinction. Once you have lived here for more than 7 years[*], you can apply to be a Hong Kong Permanent Resident.  This gives you all the rights that every Hong Kong Permanent resident has, including a vote, as useful/useless as it is, and the right of Abode, which means you can't be deported.  [*] This doesn't apply to certain categories of residents, mostly Domestic Helpers, because Hong Kong is a very racist place when it comes to people with darker skin than most Han Chinese.  What distinguishes Paulus Zimmerman from other long-term residents is that he has renounced his Dutch citizenship/Nationality to get Chinese Nationality. This enables him to stand for public office (and he's been elected for many terms, and he's a genuinely good, well intentioned guy), and has some very minor benefits additional where he can travel to Mainland China without a visa.

Hong Kong looks up in envy of the Singapore's public housing market, but for HK to mimic Singapore's housing dream, Hong Kong have to rethink urban planning and zoning of their land. Apart from that, the way Singapore managed resettlement and land acquisition plays a part if Hong Kong wants to make room for more housing. In the early 60s-70s land was bought at market rate from private owners in order to redevelop the land for housing. But for Hong Kong to do that now, billions of dollars will have to be paid back to the greedy developers/owners of the land.

How exactly would government land zoning policy reform go? Since you said yourself that it's the main source of revenue for the government, if one were to decrease this allotment, the next logical thing to do would be to raise balances to make up that deficit. Now, theoretically, you could do this with corporate tax, but chances are that a corporate tax would get pretty much nowhere thanks to the corporate lobbying powers or the threat of a pull-out and scare of an economic downturn. That leaves an personal income tax, which, if incremental sounds like it might work. However, the citizens here are clearly already squeezed for money because of housing costs. Chances are that whatever pricing effects housing policy reform enacts will be slow to percolate through the market, and housing costs would still be extremely high. So in the short/medium term, you'd be putting the squeeze on the average citizen from both a taxation stanpoint and a housing pricing standpoint, albiet maybe a few dollars cheaper a month.

Overly hasty connection - for HK, it's not about how much control/how large a role (it's role in the economy is probably one of the smallest in the world? It's "the freest market" after all). The problem is where this control should be (taxes versus housing land).
Who controls the taxes? Who controls zoning?...............................mic drop.

Both are controlled by the government, yeah of course... but what the video is trying to say is that there's TOO LITTLE tax, and TOO MUCH control on zoning.  From your conservative stand point, LESS taxes plus LESS zoning may be a good thing (it's entirely possible, idk), but this video is not talking about less/more control overall, it's about the need to balance while keeping the overall control unchanged. Not that being conservative/liberal is good or bad, but that it has nothing to do with HK's predicament at all.
Government controls over the free market usually hinder said market. HK, once one of the freest markets, is now experiencing what most countries endure. The overreach of government.
HK is still THE freest market though? It has consistently ranked 1st in the Index of Economic Freedom from 2012 to 2018. It is definitely not "once one of the freest markets".

I agree with your point about improper government intervention messing up the housing market real bad, but it is only the housing market that they're controlling. Low taxes means that the government actually has little control over the macroeconomy, which is much bigger than the housing market alone. The government still needs a certain amount of revenue - civil servants don't work for free - so if you want less control on land, then taxes have to rise. It's a trade off. But the overall amount of control should remain the same either way.

I would argue the government is not doing enough, or care enough. Then again, we don't have truly democratic elections, so there is immediately a lack of accountability. The Legislative Council is dominated by pro-Beijing suck-ups, mainly because a significant number of seats are functional constituencies elected by mainly business people who have ties to China, and even the Chief Executive is "elected" by a council of representatives that consist predominantly of business people, so there is little surprise which way government policy sways. There is little discernible difference who holds the reigns when the public and private sectors are basically one and the same.

HK was largely self-ruled (little government) prior to 1999. Affordable housing wasn't a problem then. Increasing government's role will not decrease the issue now. But obviously we know Beijing isn't going to back off HK. Government usually creates more problems than they alleviate.

When I was doing business in HK 3 years ago it was heartbreaking to see the extreme gap between the haves and have nots. Ike it's a "smart card". It basically works like a debit card but it's contactless so no swiping is involved. These types of cards can be used in anywhere from public transport to supermarkets to restaurants. It's so successful that no one really carries cash around in HK anymore. And these cards has been adapted to so many cities from Singapore, Manila, Taipei, to London, Dublin, and more.  We as Hong Kongers are extremely fond and proud of the Octopus Card

Ike adding onto what the other guy said, it's an RFID enabled card which was first introduced in 1997, and led to the creation of the oyster card in UK. It is used by 99% of the population and handles 180 million HKD worth in transactions every day.

I like low taxes but if it results in worse living conditions for those at the bottom who were doing ok, it just doesn't sit well with me. HK has been this way since World War 2 lol.The cage people are nothing new. You didn't talk about the people who live under staircases - srs.   I grew up there and as a kid had the privilege to live 'rich' in a 'huge' 2000sq ft apartment at the top of a hill. Later my family left HK but I stayed to work in my late teens without help from parents. I lived in a tiny room that only fit a queen bed - no kitchen, but very lucky to have a tiny bathroom the size of a washing machine with a plastic hose as a shower. Sitting down to use the toilet, it was so cramped that I had to shift my knees to the side, because the wall was in the way. When it rained, water would drip from the ceiling onto the bed. My window opened out to a view of an alleyway piled up with years worth of garbage lol lol. The place was so small, I used to have to leave my shoes outside my door in the communal area, only to one day wake up and find some bastrd had stolen them - so I stole my neighbour's shoes so I could head to work. Now live in Australia in my own 4 storey townhouse with 3 bathrooms and a forest in my backyard.   Living poor / average in Hong Kong, most people spend as much time as they can outdoors. I'd only eat out, and the only time I spent at my cramped apartment / room / shoebox, was to sleep. I love Hong Kong. It's the best place in the world... if you're upper middle class / rich. If you're poor / working class, Hong Kong is the biggest sh*thole ever. Social welfare is non-existent, so you're on your own really if you lose your job. Health care is great there though, and it's the safest city in the world at night.   Hong Kong FTW!

A lot of the "ghost city" myth comes from a fundamental misunderstanding of how housing works in China. When you buy a house, you rarely get it fully furnished - instead, you wait a long time, sometimes up to a year, while workers do interior renovations. You then move in after it's done. This is also exacerbated by the fact that Chinese city planners actually have power and use projections to plan ahead. What usually happens is that they end up creating large residential complexes ahead of the actual wave. In a sense, it's like how stores will stock up in advance before the Christmas sales. Taking photos of a "ghost city" is like sneaking into the warehouse and claiming that there are wasted goods.  HK people can freely move to neighboring Shenzhen, but they just don't. This isn't an availability issue, nor is it a blockage issue. It's just preference. They want to live in HK, under HK's system, even if it's never really served the people as a UK colony and even today as a Chinese SAR.

@Random Youtube Idiot I think a Socialist policy is when the government owns what gets produced, generally through taxes and redistribution, which can result in better living conditions as long as there is no obstruction of what gets produced.   A Communist policy is when the Government owns the land and rents it out, which can result in better living conditions depending on how well people use the land.   A Capitalist policy is when the Government protects the citizen property and taxes to fund such protection which can result in better living for the people if the people become wealthy and look after each other.  A Fascist policy is when the Government owns the land and owns what is produced and protects itself which can result in better living conditions for the people if the Government is very capable.   I think the cycle is that it starts off Capitalist, then when the rich don't look after the poor, the government becomes Socialist as the Government steps in. Then it becomes Communist because there isn't enough tax money to help the poor and the Government tries to let only effective people have access.   Which works as long as the people don't go elsewhere to work. Then the Government become Fascist for as long as they have capable people who will make sacrifices. When that runs out, the Government start enslaving and running out of the local population who will make sacrifices usually means they have to go to war to get land and people from other countries to enslave.  Then if they win and after people are assimilated, the Government can become Capitalist again.   I think Governments are trying to break out of the cycle through and it's interesting because it seems like having some mechanisms of the previous parts of the cycle present can keep the Government from progressing to the next part of the cycle and there might be some formula for that. But it also raises the question if such progressions are necessary to evolve to a higher level of development, assuming that each cycle make things progressively better. And the danger that the next evolution leads to extinction.  Or I may be completely wrong. It's just interesting to think about.

B Jiang you're being with lazy your semantics and with definitions. When you see something that is close but not quite a fit to the mental model you're used to, keep your mouth shut, go study, and figure out what this new close form really is.  An analogy would be horses and unicorns (if unicorns were real). A horse is a horse; a unicorn is kind of a horse but not quite, so we have a different name for it. There are lots of things in life don't quite fit the typical model we are used to when we encounter them. Be careful, be thoughtful and be willing to put in extra effort when such situations arise. The government gets the majority of its revenue through other sources such as the land auctions in order to stay competitively low in taxes. Land scarcity is not the real problem. Behind that is how money is traded. The idea that money is a commodity is wrong, money should only be used as a MEDIUM of exchange, not as a substance in itself. Starting with the idea of interest as money rather than as genuine, "I lend you money therefore I have an interest in what you do with it" and progressing from there through making money on variable currency exchange rates right up to deliberate fixing patterns and dirty credit trading there is one result: Pools of money slop around the world through e-trading of credits growing and growing like tsunamis of credit that draw value out of local communities into finance trading systems leaving the poor poorer and making the rich richer. Anytime we trade in money itself or gain from interest that we are not genuinely interested in we contribute to the problems this video discusses.

When you illustrate it like that, capitalism seems like a consummate paradigm. In reality, this is not the case. Capitalism, as Adam Smith expressed in his "Wealth of Nations," follows the theoretical practice of laissez-faire economics - essentially, "let-it-be" economics. In this case, the government is obliged to not interfere in the free market. This agrees with your 'solution' that a government should "lift the strict regulations on businesses and cut taxes on the rich." What you fail to grasp is the notion that capitalism only functions with an upper class and a lower class. The upper class will exploit the labors of the lower. This is self-evident: pick up a history textbook and read the genesis of the Industrial Revolution, especially in Great Britain. This disparity of authority is specifically what implored Karl Marx to write "Das Kapital," one of many stepping stones towards the road of socialism. Fundamentally, as the rich get richer, the poor get poorer. The horrors of such a capitalistic climate resulted in the British government to institute socialist policies like mandatory education, regulations, and healthcare. This 'solution' you talk about isn't a solution at all: it is simply one of many impulsive and unsubstantiated claims that will do much more harm than benefit.

Hong Kong's revenue policy is correct, but here are Hong Kong's problems:  1. Their revenue policy doesn't go far enough. Did you notice how in the auctions, the land sold for fixed dollar amounts, and not periodic ones ($x per month)? Those aren't leaseholds. They're 50-year (or 99-year, or whatever) freeholds. There should be no up-front, fixed selling price for land because "government" should be leasing out the land at full market rental value.  2. What does the HK government do with the revenue? Does it return it as compensation directly to the people? No. Bad things happen when the government gatekeeps the money supply and makes people work for it. Did you hear the narrator say, "This is great for the government, but not so much for the people..." Yeah. This is what we geo-libertarians keep trying to tell people. Without a Residents' Dividend (RD), what the hell is the point of public land rent collection? To make "government" -- whoever owns that, because without the RD, the people don't -- better off.  3. Zoning, but this isn't as important as the video implies. Of course, leasehold land title auctions can only cause land use efficiency on land the government allows to be used. This might result in bigger rooms -- temporarily, anyway -- but it won't make people economically better off. The above points -- getting land rent in the hands of the people -- will.   Misconceptions perpetuated by this video:  1. Small living spaces are bad. There is nothing good or bad about them. It's an indication that an area -- in this case, Hong Kong -- is in high demand. When a small location like Hong Kong is put to full, market-demanded use, the result will be small living spaces. If you don't like living in a small space, move out of Hong Kong and make way for a land user who is willing to live in close proximity with other people.  2. Changing Hong Kong's revenue model will accomplish something good. It won't. If you start taxing businesses, they'll start moving out of town, and Hong Kong loses. This is what every other place on Earth does, and right now, everyone goes to Hong Kong. The answer is to keep doing what they do (recurring land title auctions); do it more and better (collect the full rent); and spend the proceeds correctly, returning it as compensation to each resident, directly and equally.  If you want more clarity on this, join me on Twitch sometime.  www.twitch.tv/ask_a_geoist

As a Hong kong citizen, I think there are more reasons behind the ridiculous housing market.  1 - we have 0 inheritance tax (doesn't matter if the property is owned by a company / personnel) - this leads to many wealthy from all over the world buying properties in Hong Kong as a way to pass on their wealth onto their next generation.  2 - For the last 10 years or so, Hong Kong has super lower interest rate, with the global boom of money supplies, many hot money (from all over the world &/ China has gone into the system)  3 - As part of China (but not really China, since we have our own government, legal & tax system), many Chinese investors feel much safer to have their money 'park here' in Hong Kong instead of China, thus making it a very popular spot for investment.   4 - Except (3), Hong Kong has also been a very popular spot for mainland Chinese to relocate to - since we have much better government benefits and health care system, as well as free education up to year 9. This directly leads to more than 1mil increase in population, where we only had roughly 7mil before 1997, which is a 1/7 increase over 20 years, the rest is really demand and supply of the housing market.  5 - Policy - I agree to the point of which the video makes, however, i do not think it is entirely because they do not want the price down. Hong Kong, as part of China but not so part of China, may seem to have our own system. But in reality, government officials are merely dolls of the China's highest officials. Since Hong Kong has returned to China in 1997, our government has been rubbish. In Hong Kong, we have a saying for Hong Kong's official's culture "The less you do, the less could go wrong. The more you do, the more could go wrong" - leading Hong Kong to slowly die out in comparison to other international major cities in the world, not only in the real estate market, but in many aspects, such as healthy care, legal, technology, etc.  I think there are some more reason but imo, these are the main ones. Which would you sacrifice?  Green space for building houses? or Houses for green space?   Before you answer, I'd like to enlighten you with some details on each choice. If you choose to sacrifice green space to build houses, environmental NGOs will complain to the government, start protests, and create riots within the city. If you choose to sacrifice houses for green space, citizens will complain about the land problem. The problem is, whichever choice you make, you still *can't win.* If the government got rid of green space to build houses, we'd eventually run out of space again. What do we do? Get rid of more green space! Until there's absolutely no green space, there will be citizens complaining about how the housing prices are still ridiculously high. If the government saved the green spaces for environmental purposes, we'd have no choice but to fill the ocean with land "å¡«æµ·" or else people will complain about housing prices. Filling the ocean is not the best idea either. It is costly and drives away precious sea life which live in Hong Kong's surrounding waters. I think the government is trying their best to achieve "é›™è´" (win-win) solution for the housing problem. For now, there IS no win-win situation. So the government must choose to sacrifice either our green space, our housing space, or our sea life. That is my opinion on this. Thanks for reading this long paragraph. The real problem isn't land scarcity, it's government supported gentrification. The government thinks these subdivided flats are a 'disgrace' - which they are, and try to fix it by knocking down all the old buildings and building shiny new, private and EXPENSIVE developments with developers. These new developments are conpletely unaffordable for the people who have been turfed out, and they are forced into the ungentrified areas, cramming even more people into already atrocious conditions. Until the government mans up,and either 1) builds more 'new towns'- massive greenfield developments in the rural areas of HK, with everything you need to live there and good transport to central HK, or 2) faces down developers and makes laws mandating the construction of affordable/public housing, the problem is only going to get worse.

Socialists/Capitalists: this is clear evidence of the failure of socialist/capitalist policy. Me, a Georgist: this honestly not a failure of government or free markets, just bad land policy. Honestly, the Hong Kong tax revenue system actually makes a lot of sense... if the Hong Kong government didn't own all the land. What Vox failed to mention was that Hong Kong also implements a land value tax as part of its land lease system. If they were to free up all government land and simply shifted more over to a land value tax (with a few changes to zoning laws as well), their land policy would likely be far more effective.

Just a little add-on note - Vox probably didn't have time to cover this point in a 10-minute video but another reason that the prices can keep rising and rising without ever falling significantly is that many of the buyers for new apartments are now not from Hong Kong. Since the vast majority of people in Hong Kong can't afford to buy a new apartment, you'd expect that eventually the price would fall when they get so astronomically expensive that buyer numbers drop - but since there is a never-ceasing influx of wealthy buyers from out of Hong Kong, especially from the mainland, the number of willing and able buyers never drops, no matter how high the price continues to rise.

I read a sci fi short story a few years ago. It was published in the late 70ies, and described a dystopic future, where people lived so cramped, that they could barely walk on the street. Most housing units were a few square meters (thus smaller than a parking space) or two slightly larger "flats" stacked on top of each others. The land lords were vicious, greedy, corrupt, and prone to even the most horrifying suppression of their tenants.   Little did I realize, that this was becoming true, and worse: even worse. I am so grateful, that I live in a small market town in rural Denmark. I can afford a 74 square meter (800 square feet) two bedroom apartment/flat, and it even comes with fairly cheap district heating, a small supermarket just across the street, three playgrounds, a laundromat, and free parking spaces.   The only (really minute) downside is, that the linoleum flooring in the kitchen is butt ugly, and I have to pay a floor layer out of my own pocket, if I want to replace it. Seriously, it was butt ugly back in the mid 80ies, and it hasn't aged well. But that is all the bad things there are to say about it. Goodness, I feel lucky after watching this.

What this video fails to communicate is that, the low tax rate also benefits the people.  Hong Kong's income tax rate is at 15% flat across wage levels. Yet the city has one of the best health care systems, public transit systems, and infrastructures in the world.  And without a real manufacturing industry, the low corporate tax rate attracts banks, investment companies, and other trade entities to do business in the city (Hong Kong ranks 37 on lowest unemployment rate at 3.2% in 2017 by the World bank). Also a low tax rate is to keep itself competitive against raising cities like Shanghai from taking businesses away.  So there is really more to the problem than "oh the government should fix the policy"

This is BS... Hong kong have 1106 square km of land so if 75.6 percent of it is undeveloped, then around 270 square km or 24.4 percent is useable.. Hong kong's population is 7.437 million. Dividing the useable land to each person, 270,000,000 sq. m divided by 7,437,000 equals 36.3 sq. m per person! Assuming only one third of it is used for residential and the rest is for roads, stores, etc., each person can still have 12.1 sq. m of land! If a family of three live together, they can have 36.3 sq. m house! Then hong kong buildings have around 1 is to 10 floor area ratio. Meaning a 12.1 sq. m lot can have ten house stacked on top of each other so 10 people can live in a 12.1 sq. m lot while still having a 12.1 sq. m room per person making the useable area ten times as big. Now look at all those buildings. I'd assume they are probably more than 50 floors and have around 1000 units each building. So how can they have a shortage especially if most of them live in 7-14 sq. m? This is what happens when you let chinese buy/rent land.

The 85000 plan is partly executed. In 2000, 85710 units built under the plan was completed. In 2001, the num reached 100000. Many transit-oriented developments also followed the plan. Asian financial crisis is the reason for "significant" price drop doesn't mean that the 85000 plan didn't help stabilizing the housing price. As a counterexample, only 19800 units were built in 2010, & next year the price exceeded the asset bubble point in Oct 1997. Termination of the plan terminated a good tool to sustain the stability of HK housing price. Housing price should & can be controlled. Youâ€™re right HKâ€™s housing problem isnâ€™t exactly land scarcity. But as you can see from the video, available land for developing housing can be scattered and disconnected from central business districts. Developers have brought land from more rural areas just to stock up their land reserve and wait for the right time to develop. But without adequate infrastructure to support, private developers wonâ€™t have the incentive to build housing. Thereâ€™s been suggestions about how a public private partnership can work, like government providing infrastructural support to unleash the potential of  private land in rural districts. But if youâ€™re familiar with HK politics(which i assume youâ€™re not), public is very sensitive to gov collusion with big businesses, especially these property tycoons. So this suggestion doesnâ€™t garner sufficient public support. Another suggestion is to have the government to resume these private land from property developers to build public housing (thereâ€™s a law where gov can take away land if they do it for public purpose and compensate the developers fairly). Yet again this is a tricky thing to do, because it involves challenges against private property right (which HK as a free market take pride in) and what constitutes as a â€œfairâ€ compensation can result in very huge amount of money, which may not necessarily be the best use of public revenue. So as you can see thereâ€™s land in HK, but itâ€™s not a simple matter of mathematic calculations. I have only listed two of the many obstacles for developing housing here, and itâ€™s already complicated enough that the city doesnâ€™t exactly has a solution for

The thing is, no matter what you do you cannot escape from taxes. The HK government has managed to tax people without calling it a tax (which is a popular thing for governments to do now.) What this video didnt't mention is that the Hong Kong government is unwilling to solve the housing problem.  This is evident by: 1) allowing a large influx of chinese immigrants to move into Hong Kong. There have been larger than a million of new immigrants (1/8 of the total population!) in the last 10 years after the handover, and there's no housing program that can accommodate such a large influx in a short time.   2) The HK gov has been advocating (and partially forcing through this housing problem) citizens to move into the "Great bay Area", which are the neighboring cities like Shenzhen, Zhuhai etc.  This could be a solution, except for the fact that there is a giant border between Hong Kong and China.  Of course there is a bigger political incentive behind this - ultimately China want to achieve this so-called "one hour living circle", in this way they can completely fuse Hong Kong into China, and use it an excuse to demolish the border between Hong Kong and China early before the promised 50-years of political stabilliy.

Yes, the housing price in Hong Kong went up, but no, average living space per person actually went up in the past 20 years. It was just 20 years ago that it is usual to see three generations of people living under the same roof together, now, each generation demands and tries to buy their own space, and particularly demands in the core urban areas. This growth in demand far exceeds available lands and what zoning law changes can provide.  Also, another point that makes this a poor research is. There are reasons why the HK Gov't is unable to designate lands in the suburban areas, there are a lot of flat lands are entitled to the descendants of original villagers living in the areas prior to the British took over in 1899, and for the rest of the flat lands, most of them already bought up by major developers in anticipation of zoning changes. So, the HK Gov't is left with two choices, either violated inheritance rights or being accused of channeling profits to friendly developers.

The real problem as he mentions at the end is that housing is way too expensive for the average joe and the gov't has little incentive to do anything about it. The fundamental economic source of a price increase is low supply, high demand. As he mentioned, there's still land that's available, but it's up to the gov't to give it out at lower prices and encourage developers to build up (increase supply). While this is great for those who don't own homes or rent, it's not attractive to home owners who want to maximize their real estate value and in turn keep housing supply low.

Okay, there's a lot of people here arguing about whether this is the government's fault, or the market's fault. I'm more inclined to say it's the government's fault, but here's a different take from the majority of what I see; the problem isn't land usage, it's zoning.  As stated in the video, only a minuscule 3.7% of the land is zoned for housing. Sure, 75% of the land on the island is unused, but out of the land that is used, the fraction used for housing is tiny. Running the numbers, residential zones make up <1% of the island. Free up just 1.2% of that unused land and zone it specifically for high-density housing, and you've doubled the housing supply.  If I'm missing something here, someone let me know. Maybe zoning in HK doesn't work how I think it does.

Why does Hong Kong have the most unaffordable cost of accommodation? This should be a good question to the UK government! There have been structural problems of land supply shortage in HK due to the  'high-land-price policy'. Before the returning of HK to the mainland China in 1997, HK kept implementing the 'high-land-price' policy so that the cost of governance of HK by the British HK government could be minimized. The government can be benefited from High land price through high tax revenue from land auction and stamp duty. The British HK government actually colluded with a few major real estate developers in HK to monopolize the land market in HK. The government collect high profit tax from the high profit earned by land developers. The high land rent cost is actually a kind of implicit tax on every HK citizen. But ironically, the despicable British HK government kept saying HK is a tax paradise with low tax rate. HK is indeed a tax paradise with simple tax laws if you only regard the explicit tax which can be 'seen' but it is not the whole fact if you also consider the high 'rent'.  All these were time bombs setup by the despicable British government before the returning of HK to the mainland China. And now this high-land-price bomb is hard to be dismantled because major part of the wealth were in the form of real estate for most of the landlord class in HK. Any policy that would lower the land price and move their cheese will have a horrible effect and political risks to the HK government now. So.... Who are brave enough to be this superman??  The UK government should be blamed inevitably !!

when my parents and my grandparents lived in ukraine in the 90s, they werent very wealthy they lived in a small apartment on the ground floor i think it was 5 people living in 40m2, that makes 8m2 per person they lived in harkov, at the time the city had 800 000 residents, now its over a million but they rarely fought with their family or even their neighbours,  on the contrary: whenever she could, my grandmother would invite all of her friends in the apartments over her to come eat something and drink a tea ( and maybe some vodka )  it was usual for the guests to bring some food with them, like for example a box of cookies, a salad or some saussage they were basically living like a family, not like people who "have to get along" the story was very similar when they came to germany in the 2000s my grandmother, grandfather, my mother and her future husband lived together in a small "immigrantenheim"  basically germany gave them a place to stay until they learned the language and found work to be able to afford their own place again, they didnt have much space and they lived in the same house with total strangers from diffrent countries just 2 doors away my father also lived in that house, he came with some other people from his country, he didnt know them tho  he only talked serbian but the langauge was rather similar to ukrainian/russian so he and my family understood each other "good enough" in this situation, with next to nothing and strangers all around these days in my generation it would be a fierce battle but they had a great time! every day they would bring a table outside and drink tea / try food from their neighbours they basically didnt understand each other but it was enough to say " come outside were smoking " my parents say it was great fun and they got along very well  i dont think that could happen again these days ive never seen anything like it.

the video's point IS that only 3.1% of the land is densely populated. It's pointing out that the problem that causes the housing shortage isn't that there's not enough land, but rather, the land isn't being built on.

What, you want to just bulldoze all these village homes? Do you know the engineering challenges involved with building such tall buildings in remote areas with rough terrain like these? The infrastructure in these areas is nowhere near enough to build such skyscrapers. Many people in the villages don't even have gas lines and must buy barrels, many of the roads are unpaved gravel. Much of the land that is appropriate is being used, and the appropriate unused land is slowly being used up. There are actually several high-density properties being put up near where I live. Also, the terminology used "high density" is very vague and not described in the video.

There's no need to 'bulldoze village homes', calm down. There's a fair amount of (flat terrained) land in Hong Kong that isn't being occupied at all. For those who try to blame China on freedom of speech and press: criticising China is (politically) correct but meaning less to people who struggle in coffin rooms. The real problem is, it is easier to survive in Hong Kong than in mainland China in almost all perspectives. If you are not a super rich, ordinary blue collar even have problem adapting life style in nearby Guangdong, despite the barrier set by Chinese government to discourage internal migration.
There's a lot of Chinese people from China here in Orange County.

The biggest issue is that there's a hard border between China and Hong Kong, with unpredictable customs delays as well as stuff like residency rights, currencies and major differences in language. The other is poor public transport connectivity which increases commute time, although they're building a high speed rail link. And finally real estate prices over the border are rising fast, which limits the incentive to move for poorer HKers.  If there's a Schengen arrangement between HK and China I'll bet you a very substantial amount of HKers will pack up and move north. Freedom and democracy are difficult to justify if HKers living up north has a substantially higher standard of living because of lower house prices. This is also why no one in Ireland or NI wants the return of a hard border with Brexit.  With HK being further assimilated into China, you can bet it'll probably turn into a city like Basel, where people can work on the Swiss side, live on the French side, and shop on the German side. It's just better if you want to maximize your earning potential and living standard.

The housing problem in Hong Kong is a multi-layered problem - and its giving these cage homes (most of which are illegal in one way or another) a chance to thrive. Lets look at the average salary of a person working a graduate job or a low-skilled job. It hovers around the 13000 - 18000 HKD mark. One of those tiny cages cost 2000-3000 HKD to rent. If you're looking at those smaller subdivided apartments - at least double. With poor hygiene, poor maintenance of the flats (look at the collapse of one such building at Ma Tau Wai Road), having to share communal facilities, it is terrible living conditions for the lowest-earners.   The Hong Kong Government advocates that public housing is the best way to solve this problem, whilst staying out of the free-market. They are simply building them way too slow. The average wait for a public housing apartment has gone up to five years. More and more people are applying for them and the queue is getting longer at a rate which the government isn't building fast enough. For a city that has a massive budget surplus, it is disappointing that welfare for one of Hong Kong's biggest social problems isn't the priority for the government. It means that graduates like me have to continue to live with my parents well until my late-twenties (until I start earning enough to move out) and that poorer people are praying that they will be picked for public housing sooner than the five year wait.  Estate prices are now at an all-time high in Hong Kong's history, and with it the government has unsuccessfully tried to implement market controls to stop the inflation by limiting Mainland Chinese investment by implementing tax for short-term sales of property. But it doesn't work because many of the investors choose to hold onto the properties, renting them out at this ridiculous rate and knowing that it will be very profitable in 5/10 years time. My Grandma's apartment which sold two years ago at 10 million HKD, now has a value of 12 million. This is not sustainable and this also further limits the affordability of cheap housing for low-income earners or those relying on government support.   The government is making extremely large amounts of money by leasing land, and such a large part of the economy relies upon estate pricing to remain high - it will seriously damage Hong Kong's economy (as it has done before) if the market crashes.  Unfortunately, it doesn't seem like the market nor the government is doing enough to help the poorer people of Hong Kong, and it's a problem that will likely get worse in the future as they don't have a big incentive to.

There are similar living conditions/ accommodations in Alaska. When I lived up there I found boarding houses where they would take a three-bedroom apartment and subdivided into six bedrooms. That was actually pretty common thing. I also found mobile homes/ trailers where they would subdivide bedrooms and the living rooms into  two bedrooms. They would even frequently make mudrooms, porch, garages and car ports into extra bedrooms. Most places I found that were subdivide like that typically would charge anywhere between $200 a month per bed up to even $700 a month per bed. Some times it was even common to find bunkbeds in these accommodations.  It is also common to find these types of accommodations in  college towns and in vacation beach towns, and not just for vacation rentals. They were mostly rented by single  men with low incomes as a step up from being homeless or having to stay in homeless shelters.  In cities here in the US where I've mostly found these types of accommodations the average studio apartment or 1-bedroom apartment were going for more than $800 a month.

Where would they go? Hong Kong is an autonomous region of its own. It isn't like in the US where you can just move out of state. Their passports are separate from those issued in mainland China. Most would be reluctant to move to China, due to censorship and freedom of speech concerns, and to emigrate abroad you would need to go through a rigorous immigration process, which let's face it, the people who need to 'leave the city' most can't afford. Plus, it's not easy to transition to living in a country whose culture is drastically different from yours, and who speak a different language.

A lot of people who live in coffin homes and subdivided units are actually unemployed and being given benefits (called Comprehensive Social Security Assistance). This may be because they are elderly, disabled, or just not allowed to work because of legal stipulations (I know a girl who was under 18 and therefore obligated to attend school). So they wouldn't actually be commuting to work. As for why they don't live in China â€” I don't think they would get as comprehensive benefits if they weren't residing in Hong Kong.

In Sydney we face a market crisis as well, just as you described it people from mainland China seek a better retirement location in Sydney and they have inflated our market so badly that it would be almost to purchase property near the city. The government has places sanctions and increased taxes for international investments to reduce the number of overseas buyers however the damage has already been done. The influx has caused residents to move further and further away. Just for some insight the affordable properties at the moment is approximately a 1-1.5 hr drive to the city in minimum traffic, however during mornings and afternoon periods travel times may exceed 2 hrs. The state government of NSW has horridly has spent a large majority of its funds on hopeless projects that actually made no difference on the transit times to and from the city to those places and has also slapped a sky high toll on those roads or you risk a 3 hr commute to work. So the average person who can afford a house has to fork out even more money on transiting to and from work . Also our public transport is hopeless at its best, trains are rarely on time and during rush hour travel prices increase as well. Such for purchasing and owning a home closer to the city when renting would be cheaper and commutes wont be as costly. Hypothetically 20 years of mortgage combined with 20 years of travel to the city would be more expensive then rent for 20 years and much cheaper travel to the city

I just completed a Bachelorâ€™s degree in economics from a Hong Kong institution and yeah I doubt change would happen. As stated in the video, a disproportionate amount of fiscal revenue is based on land (around 70 - 80%) if Iâ€™m not wrong, this would account not just the lease but also property tax, rental income, etc. Opening up more land (increasing supply) will significantly depreciate fiscal revenue. It would put pressure on the infamous flat tax system of the region and the governments ability to provide assistance (i.e. public housing). In a roundabout way, Iâ€™ve heard people say the reason why they shouldnâ€™t do drastic change is by redistribution through assistance which is ludicrous. Another thing, the lease system incentivise property developer to build luxury housing which is bought for investment purposes (mainly by Mainland), so itâ€™s not just housing that is scarce; itâ€™s affordable housing to be exact.   P.S. IDK if this is TL/DR, but as someone who lived there for four years, I would argue that living condition is damn near unlivable even for government approved minimum dimension, which says something. So hope Iâ€™m wrong on the change part.

In certain markets, artificial scarcity brings in the greatest revenue. For instance, diamonds are not as rare as you might think and if they were all sold in the free market, they would be practically worthless. Hence, De Beers stockpiles diamonds to control the supply, artificially increasing the price given demand. The Hong Kong government is doing the same, only with land.

The HK gov kinda painted themselves into a corner here. Since the corporate and income tax rate is so low, there's no sales tax and there exists a very simple tax system, the only real way for the government to raise revenue is through land sales. Now land sales involves the real estate developers and the wealthy Chinese investors from the north. If the government suddenly relaxes land supply, the real estate prices are gonna plummet, that makes for a lot of very unhappy and very powerful people in China.

That's not really true, 323guiltyspark. If diamonds had a free market (they kind of do since the de beers monopoly no longer exists), they'd still be valuable, since lower price would then decrease the incentive to mine them, decreasing supply. It's not that diamonds are that easy to get, it's that they're so valuable they're ridiculously more sought for than their free market value would suggest.  But even that's misleading, because the hugest component of diamond's value is that de beers successfully marketed diamonds to be a nigh-universally cherished item woven into the cultural fabric of society, massively expanding demand.

@323guiltyspark Even in a monopoly market, there still exists an optimal price point to maximise revenue depending on the price elasticity of demand. It is still more profitable to sell a million carats of diamond at $1K/carat, than just 1 carat at $1M.. As mentioned, the HK government wanted to rezone some of the country parks for development, but there has been strong oppositions from environmental groups and general public.
